author: Zeddicus11
body:
Returns since January 1st, 2020:

\- MSFT: 16.8% YTD, and makes up 5.7% of SPY

\- AAPL: 8.82% YTD, and makes up 5.1% of SPY

\- AMZN: 32.2% YTD, and makes up 4.3% of SPY

\- GOOG: 16.8% YTD, and makes up 1.7% of SPY

\- GOOGL: 17.2% YTD, and makes up 1.7% of SPY

\- FB: 9.7% YTD, and makes up 2% of SPY

Combining these 6 stocks, we get about 20.5% of SPY, with a weighted average return of 17.4%.

Meanwhile, the S&P500 had a -4.9% YTD return, which implies that the remaining 494 holdings should have had a weighted average return of around -10.7% YTD.

Basically, 6 stocks "undid" over half the damage suffered to the entire index, which is insane.

author: palopalopopa
body:
Microsoft ain't even selling Teams lmao it's FREE with cloud Office 365, which every big business already has.

People don't understand how easy it is for businesses to switch video conferencing services. Our office went from Zoom to Teams just this week and half the office didn't even notice because they just click the link in the meeting email as usual.

It's nothing like switching social media or online marketplaces or whatever, which has a ton of friction against switching. Zoom is fucked.

author: Microsoft17
body:
Pretty much. Zoom does one thing and one thing well. Teams is too complicated of a product at least for the general consumer if all you want is a simple group video call. 

Where MSFT definitely messed up though is Skype. Skype could’ve been Zoom, but it also could’ve been WhatsApp and a whole lot more. They’ve horribly mismanaged Skype for a long time.

author: zac503
body:
I was going to type a huge response, but in general, their offering has more options for fringe scenarios, a robust workflow for SIP/H.323, USB Control through peripherals, and in general just has more flexibility to meet the needs of users. That's not to say Teams is junk, it's just in catch up mode, and Microsoft seems resistant to get serious about improving a lot of common requests the client receives. 

Additionally Microsoft's workflow for collaboration with users external to the organization is more convoluted and doesn't work out of the box the same way Zoom's does. I would argue their meeting join experience is probably 50% of their success.

author: zac503
body:
Per your second point. Don't make the mistake of comparing them today. Go back 2-3 years when Zoom was the first to market with many of these quality of life items, and the fast forward to thousands of organizations being forced to adopt something that would give them synchronous video within a few weeks. If all you need is video, Zoom is cheaper, and I'd argue your average non-tecchy will understand their product far better than Teams. And when compared head to head for \*video conferencing\*, Zoom is slightly easier, slightly more performant and has a lot of features that make it easy to adopt for newbies.

For an organization already entrenched in Teams, there's no reason to change, but for an Org that is needing to buy video conferencing only, Zoom will remain arguably the stronger option until Microsoft differentiates their product better.

author: syncc6
body:
Do research and don’t buy a stock without knowing what you’re buying. Think about it, would you buy a TV, computer, phone, or house without knowing the ins and outs of the what you’re about to buy? Probably not. Treat buying a stock the same way. 

With that said, you’re probably trying to get some ideas and get some direction. 

I’d recommend buying some ETFs as they provide diversification for you. Some staples are VTI, VOO, QQQ, or SPY.

If you absolutely want to buy individual stocks, stay away from penny stocks. Go after blue chip stocks such as MSFT, GOOGL, AMZN, V, or AAPL. They are leaders in their sectors and will have strong presence 5-10+ years from now. If these are too expensive for you, try buying them in fractional shares.

But remember, always do research!

author: SleepyRevenant
body:
Everything Oracle has done since java 8 has been horrible (in before someone inevitably replies that Java 8 is horrible). They used to be THE name in data architecture and now this core business is having a train run on it by Hadoop. Imagine being so shitty that free software with a stupid name takes away your customers.

Also, Everyone hates newer Java versions so much that they made Scala, Kotlin and Jython just to avoid using them and in respect to cloud services; Microsoft has them whipped on service integration, Amazon has them whipped on flexibility, Digital ocean has them whipped on price. They just don't stand out in any field.

In this market anything could moon but, with all the options available, I can't see how Oracle is a good choice.

author: zac503
body:
It's the biggest blunder they've had, but I will say they leaned into it aggressively. They just launched their encryption update over the weekend and I'm very interested for a re-review in the coming months following their changes. 

People tend to sleep on the actual number of legitimate communication scenarios that a modern org has. Teams simply doesn't cover them all yet, and Zoom does. The shear amount of flexibility and the number of configurations they support is the best in the industry.  

Being a Microsoft customer for products like this mean you take what Microsoft wants to offer and people who are not covered end up using something else and trying to hide it from corporate IT.

author: patrickbateman02
body:
So it’s biggest competitor is Microsoft as it has teams which is way better than zoom. With that said Msft is huge. So I get why it’s at a p/e of 30. So zoom is new and techy and sexy. Let’s take all of its security flaws off the table. Let’s take that it’s just video and not much more off the table. And let’s say it’s even worth not 40 multiple. Not 50. Let’s say it’s a dumb as fuck market and let’s give them 70 multiple. 

Now work backwards. It has roughly 268 mil shares. 

Price right now is 208. 70= 208/(earnings / 268 mil).....70*(earnings /268)=208

2.667=earnings /268

Earnings =714

So roughly 179 mil per quarter. 

If Microsoft does a 34% margin. We can relax this for this sexy new start to 🙄 and say hey they are spending so much we can say ok 10% margin. Wait wait just looked they are 3% right now 😂

Anyway to justify a 70p/e at this shit margin they would need to have revenues of 6 bil

Now what analysts are saying is .09 EPs. Meaning 24 mil in net income 804 revenue. I’d say they do what they did q1. 15 cents. Say they do that and more every quarter and get a yearly EPS of 75 cents.thats a multiple of 278. For a video conferencing stock that hasn’t monetized users yet 😂😂😂

Alphabet is a pE of 29. Amazon is 112. You’re going to buy this shit ahead of those ?
